Hopkins

by S DAVID STERNBERG
The moon was on the water, the
moguls were on the porch, and the
Freshman were cleaning off the
tables. The freshman were curious
about the moguls, the moguls were '
contemplative on the moon, and the
moon was serenely oblivious of it
all. But Camp Letts had to go on
moguls or no moguls, moon or no
moon, for Freshman camp is not the
realm of these but of the freshmen.
When the first night's program
got under way, the class of 1890 came
back through the years to steal the
show through the vivid phrases of
venerable

Dr. Jesse

Holmes. The

clanging of the chains of the horsecart outside the windows; the thrill
of working under Dr Ira Remsen;
the inspired ferver of the zealots
who were the pioneers of the Hopkins history were seen clearly as
though the listeners were in the actual environment of the old Howard
street University.
What followed could be nothing
but anti-climax. Dr Shaffer, Mr Mallonee, and Mr Macauley revealed a
panorama of the University past and
present. Carrington Williams, president of the Student Council held
forth on its functions and the Honor System. Frank Baker, chairman
of the SAC, explored the intricacies
of activities finances. Jack Handlesman, president of ODK and editor
of the NEWS-LETTER took the audience on a trip behind the scenes in
activities.

With no warning whatever, the
skies opened up last 'Saturday and
cascaded a million dollars into the
lap of an amazed history department.
"We've become a Cinderella deDr Kent Roberts
Greenfield. department chairman,
partment," said

chuckling.
The

story

is a fantastic one
throughout. A shy and retiring man,
Dr John Martin Vincent, died last
week in California. When his will
was opened it was found that this
modestly living scholar had donated
a totally unsuspected fortune to the
study of history at the university
where he taught for twenty years.
The money, it seems, was made on
the stock exchange, where Dr Vincent rode speculative bubbles to the
heights of fabulous wealth while he
was apparently lost in historical
research.
Hopkins learned the news early
Saturday afternoon. As soon as the
story came over the Associated Press
wires at The Evening Sun, Hamilton
Owens, member of the editorial staff,
telephoned Dr Greenfield.
By the history department the
donation is not regarded as philanthropy alone but as the last tribute
of a well loved friend. "He was like
a father to me", stated Dr Greenfield. "He appealed to all sorts of
people and his seminars were the
joy of a graduate's life."
Until the terms of the will are revealed the exact amount and the
precise allocations to be made will
not be known.

ROTC enrollment gains
"I do not belieN;e that the current
international situation has anything
to do with this year's enrollment in
the Hopkins ROTC," said Lt Col
Barrett, in charge of the Battalion at
the Hopkins for the new school year.
There is a total of 336 students
registered for military training,
which is possibly a record enrolfment
for this battalion. A freshmen class
of 133 includes a few students who
seem to have reconsidered the problem of 'military training and signed
up although they have had a year or
two of residence at the University.
Although there is no conclusive
proof, there seems to be a trend, at
least in the past two years, to an increase in the number of Arts and
Science students. Engineers are given
the choice of two years of ROTC or
one year of a foreign language; how-

ever, Arts students are given no inducement.

station in Alaska.

be headed by Gerald B Carlton, new
student major. His new second-incommand will be Captain John Enders, battalion adjutant. The band will
be headed ,by Mr Diehl with the rank
of First lieutenant. Company Commanders are: A Company, V Janney;
B Company, E Divers; C Company,
A Smith; D Company, F Wiese; all
with the rank of captain.

Continuing to pursue its policy of
replacing vacancies in the faculty
with young blood, the University announced Saturday that nine new professors had been acquired to teach
during the school year 1930-40.
The Department of Political economy, the hardest hit of all, with the
death of Dr Barnett in 1937 and the
retirement of Dr Broadus Mitchell

by the acquirement of Harold H

Reynolds, who was awarded his PhD
at Harvard university in 1936.

and Zoology, also have added two
men to their staffs. William T Bowen
and Richard E Kimball are the
Zoology appointees, while Richard E
Thursfield and Lawrence A Riggs

Language and History courses.

H H -Schapiro has been made an
Instructor in the Romance Language
department, where he served as an
assistant instructor, last year.

President Bowman advises
wholesome doubt' in
welcoming freshmen
Dr Isaiah Bowman addressed a
gathering of some 150 freshmen in
Levering hall last Tuesday night.
The meeting was organized and officered by the student YMCA.
He asked the incoming students to
adhere to the scholastic tradition of
the Hopkins, "The truth will make us
free." He said "It is desirable for a
student to enter an institution with
a whcOlesome amount of doubt. . . if
that doubt is based on reason." Pointing out that the number of out-oftown students has always exceeded
the number of Baltimore students at
Hopkins, the President indicated the
advantages to be obtained from intellectual intercourse within the
student body. He closed with a plea
that the freshmen respect "the
beauty of facts" and never take
action without knowing what they
were doing.
Laury Dickson, as chairman, introduced various faculty members
and Bill eHammaker, who continued
the same procedure.
The meeting 'was preceded and
closed by music by Routson's orchestra. A "mixer", to allow the
freshmen to meet the faculty informally, closed the evening.

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1939

The Hopkins was a funny
place last year, and not a
very enjoyable one. There
was too much turmoil, too
much beefing, too much
noise. Too many people
were talking for the sake of talking. Too many people
didn't know what they were talking. about. Too
many people were indulging in the pleasant pastime
of destructive criticism—shouting about everything
from Administration to Fascism—for the sheer fun of
it. In short there was too much hot air.

Let's Start
From
Scratch

Let's all turn over a new leaf this year. Let's
look around and take inventory. Let's look into the
dynamics of the activity all around us and try to find
out what the score is. Let's start the year firmly
resolved to reestablish the ideals that thrilled us when
we were green freshmen, anxious to hear and quick to
believe.
Let's forget all the psuedo-sophistication that's become such a nasty integral part of our bearing since
we're here, and settle down to show the benefits of
our stay here in terms of clear, consfructive thought.
Let's try to recapture the spirit that brought us
here originally. Our great institution of thought has
had much of its brilliance rubbed off to our eyes
through contact. Familiarity tends to breed contempt,
but can be curbed to breed love.
Let's not know it all for a change. Even talking
gets monotonous after a while. Let's start listening,
denying when necessary, but affirming when true.
Let's remember that some fellows are sincere no matter which side they're on, even if they are worried
pre-meds or scholarship holders.
'Let's leave the wise guys to Europe, and become
aware of our own insignificance. Let's remember that
J Jones or S Smith derives his identity here not on
his own, but from the University.
Let's start building up for a change instead of tearing down. It's harder, but more permanent. . . .
This is honestly the welcome to end all welcomes.
Two weeks of frenzied hello-ing are enough for anyone. Even a good thing can
be overdone. . . .
. . . So we're going to confine ourselves not to
further tales of the size of )our class, or how wonderful you boys are. Maybe a few tips on some of
the things we've noticed during three years of close
observation and participation in campus affairs would
be a little more welcome. We're not omniscient nor
have we less than our share of failings, but, forced
into the position of observer, we've seen a good deal.

Dedicated
to all tired
Freshmen

The Hopkins holds out to you practically unlimited possibilities in every field—the scholastic and
activities scenes, the fraternity and social life, the
contacts you have anticipated for so many years are
all here. Make the most of them.
It'll take you roughly two years to get wise to
yourselves. The two years will be gone before you've
really settled down. But it's during this formative
period that you determine exactly what you're to
derive from a college education. Your ultimate aim
must be to reach a stage where a healthy questioning
skepticism—not a smart cynicism—accompanies your
absorption of new materials.
Well, now how does one go about this?
If we could answer that we'd be great educators.
All we can hope to do is pass on a few don'ts. First,
don't try too hard to be a campus bigwig. It's never

worth it. The same amount of effort turned to other
lines yields twice the returns. A healthy activities
program for any man includes two interests: the
first in a job that is concurrent with scholastic fields,
the second, purely for relaxation. Beyond, this they
demand a disproportionate sacrifice of time and
energy.
Don't rush into fraternity if you go at all. The
fraternity rushers will state their advantages, but
make sure you select the proper group, else you will
be inactive outside the bunch, or miserable in it.
Don't take campus politics too seriously. They're
swell fun, but rotten. business. Never set your heart
on a political job, for there never was the campus politician not doomed to ultimate failure.
Don't neglect your fun, but most of all don't neglect
your studies. Take another tip, they're your best bet
and the most thrilling experience in store for you.
All eyes are focussed on
the activities of the Student
council for the next few
weeks. Left a heritage of
action and battle, the Council must show through its actions whether its policy is to be one of headlong—at
times headstrong—plunging, or of more pacific, planned action, or possibly, one of inertia.

Advice
to the
War torn

Strange as it may seem, we strongly urge the
adoption of a policy somewhere between the two latter alternatives. A little careful consideration reveals
the wisdom of the suggestion.
First, for better or for worse, we have no Ricards
on the Council this year. Casting no asperations on
Carrington Williams, whose past record has certainly
left nothing to be desired, there is no one on the Council with the pugnacious aggressiveness that the last
Fuehrer posessed.
Second, the men are, in all but the case of Haines,
entirely without experience. Certainly, dangerous
things can be done during their period of learning
unless caution is to be the motto.
Third, there isn't such an awful lot to be done.
Last year's Council, aggressive throughout, accomplished most of the reforms which it set out to achieve.
The incumbent Council may undo the work of years
if it undertakes too ambitious a program.
Nevertheless, what has remained to be done must
be done. A good start has been made on solving the
assembly problem once and for all. The interfraternity rushing question must be settled. Elections and
politics still await a thorough investigation. The
S A C has once again slumped on the job. There's
certainly enough to be done without resorting to last
year's legislation for material.
We're happy that the Council has seen fit to continue last year's referendum, recall, open meetings policy. The boys are earnest and intelligent. We look
forward to a good program of activity, with a rest from
rash action.
The portrait of a kindly
little t-nan with sparkling
eyes which look down upon
the history seminar/ room
in Gilman hall gained added
meaning this week. For with
his death, the history department became a million
dollars richer and gained the opportunity to become
the country's leading center of historical study.

The Pumpkin
Coach Arrives

In the glitter of such suddenly acquired riches the
donor is liable to be forgotten. Yet he has profoundly
influenced the Univ_ersity, its scholastic achievements,
and its traditions.
By the time Dr Vincent retired in 1925, he was
acknowledged one of America's leading historians. A
scholar of perfect integrity, he greatly resembled Dr
Tenney Frank, former Latin professor. 'His broad outlook synthesized geography, economics, and literature
with what is more orthodoxly considered history.
Through a keen interest in how people actually lived
and an insight into social institutions, he was able to
recreate the atmosphere of other times.
But despite his achievements as a social historian,
Dr Vincent was greatest in the field of historical
method. Always a careful craftsman (carpentry was
his hobby) he tested his ideas for years before publishing Aids to Historical Research and Historical
Research.
Although small in amount, the quality of his writing was high. He was interested in history well writen and his style was embellished by a tinge of irony
and a delicious sense of the comical.
Apart from the value to Hopkins of Dr Vincent's
prodigous gift, it is pleasant to think that the memory
and the influence of this most unostentatious of men
will be perpetuated for many years to come.

The Hopkins was a funny
place last year, and not a
very enjoyable one. There

From
Scratch

Let's all turn over a new leaf this year. Let's
look around and take inventory. Let's look into the
dynamics of the activity all around us and try to find
out what the score is. Let's start the year firmly
resolved to reestablish the ideals that thrilled us when
we were green freshmen, anxious to hear and quick to
believe.
Let's forget all the psuedo-sophistication that's become such a nasty integral part of our bearing since
we're here, and settle down to show the benefits of
our stay here in terms of clear, consfructive thought.
Let's try to recapture the spirit that brought us
here originally. Our great institution of thought has
had much of its brilliance rubbed off to our eyes
through contact. Familiarity tends to breed contempt,
but can be curbed to breed love.
Let's not know it all for a change. Even talking
gets monotonous after a while. Let's start listening,
denying when necessary, but affirming when true.
Let's remember that some fellows are sincere no matter which side they're on, even if they are worried
pre-meds or scholarship holders.
'Let's leave the wise guys to Europe, and become
aware of our own insignificance. Let's remember that
J Jones or S Smith derives his identity here not on
his own, but from the University.
Let's start building up for a change instead of tearing down. It's harder, but more permanent. . . .
This is honestly the welcome to end all welcomes.
Two weeks of frenzied hello-ing are enough for anyone. Even a good thing can
be overdone. . . .

further tales of the size of )our class, or how wonderful you boys are. Maybe a few tips on some of
the things we've noticed during three years of close
observation and participation in campus affairs would
be a little more welcome. We're not omniscient nor
have we less than our share of failings, but, forced
into the position of observer, we've seen a good deal.

to all tired

activities scenes, the fraternity and social life, the
contacts you have anticipated for so many years are
all here. Make the most of them.

really settled down. But it's during this formative
period that you determine exactly what you're to
derive from a college education. Your ultimate aim
must be to reach a stage where a healthy questioning
skepticism—not a smart cynicism—accompanies your
absorption of new materials.

don't try too hard to be a campus bigwig. It's never
